pullRequest.body:
Let `R` be with `Semiring R` and `TopologicalSpace R`
In this file we define the topology on `MvPowerSeries σ R`
that corresponds to the simple convergence on its coefficients,
aka the product topology.
It is the coarsest topology for which all coefficients maps are continuous.

When `R` has `UniformSpace R`, we define the corresponding uniform structure.

When the type of coefficients has the discrete topology,
it corresponds to the topology defined by [bourbaki1981], chapter 4, §4, n°2

Coauthored with María Inés de Frutos Fernández @mariainesdff 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.MvPowerSeries.PiTopology`|1117|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.PowerSeries.PiTopology`|1150|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ prod_add_one`
`+ prod_one_add`
`+ variables_tendsto_zero`
`++ as_tsum`
`++ continuous_C`
`++ continuous_coeff`
`++ continuous_constantCoeff`
`++ hasSum_of_monomials_self`
`++ instCompleteSpace`
`++ instT0Space`
`++ instT2Space`
`++ instTopologicalRing`
`++ instTopologicalSemiring`
`++ instUniformAddGroup`
`++ tendsto_iff_coeff_tendsto`
`++ tendsto_pow_of_constantCoeff_nilpotent_iff`
`++ tendsto_pow_zero_of_constantCoeff_nilpotent`
`++ tendsto_pow_zero_of_constantCoeff_zero`
`++ uniformContinuous_coeff`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#14865~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
A question to @jcommelin : shouldn't we name this file `PiTopology`?
bot fix style
Good idea to have both files in the same PR. I get to write twice as few comments 😁
Here are some more comments.
Renaming the file to `PiTopology` sounds good to me.
Good idea to have both files in the same PR. I get to write twice as few comments 😁
Here are some more comments.
Would you mind renaming alpha to something that sounds a bit more like a topological ring? Like `R` or `A`?
No I don't. (Actually, I had get acquainted to these greek letters in mathlib3, and this comes out former lean3 code…)

Do you need the `section`, or is the `namespace` enough?
```suggestion
namespace WithPiTopology

variable [TopologicalSpace α]
```
namespace should be enough (they keep variables within the namespace… end, but that wasn't so clear a few months ago)

```suggestion
end WithPiTopology

namespace WithPiUniformity
```

```suggestion
```
Here I want to keep some variables and the `open…`

```suggestion
```

Hmm, where do we teach Lean to treat `MvPowerSeries` as functions that send an index to a coefficient? Because I think that is probably confusing, and I would prefer if we avoid that spelling.

What do you think?
The problem is that `MvPowerSeries` are intrinsically functions, and sometimes lean makes conversions in that direction. So I agree that we should have this equality in the other direction.
I changed the direction and the name to `apply_eq_coeff` and will investigate why it is at all necessary.

OK, now I understand: when I define the topology as being `Pi.topologicalSpace`, it automatically refers to the power series as functions. This gives access to everything that `Pi.topologicalSpace` furnishes, in particular lemmas such as `continuous_pi_iff`. But then we need to rewrite the application as a coeff.

I am not sure it is useful to duplicate the `Pi.topologicalSpace` API here, replacing all such applications with `MvPowerSeries.coeff`.
I'm happy with the changes to this file. If you split it into a separate PR, then it could be merged already.
In fact, it was already merged a few days ago, I wonder how the `merge master` did spot a difference here.

Please move this to a better home.

If you write `#find_home! Finset.prod_one_add` below it, then Lean will give you some candidates. (Hopefully good ones.)
This looks like it uses the "evil" coercion to function.

Indeed. BUT: there is a nice feature (I believe) of `MvPowerSeries` that its type does not impose anything on the coefficients. On the other hand, `MvPowerSeries.coeff` expects a `Semiring`.
Maybe the best would be to delete `continuous_component` for the moment.
This is what I did.
Don't we have this for any pi space?
Please reuse instances about general Pi types as much as possible. If we don't have some instance, then we should add it instead of proving it in a special case.
We do. Thanks for noting.
I think that both instances should live in the same scope.

Everything is now in MvPowerSeries.WithPiTopology

Same for PowerSeries.WithPiTopology

```suggestion
- If `R` is a topological (semi)ring, then so is `MvPowerSeries σ R`.
- If the topology of `R` is T0 or T2, then so is that of `MvPowerSeries σ R`.
- If `R` is a `UniformAddGroup`, then so is `MvPowerSeries σ R`.
- If `R` is complete, then so is `MvPowerSeries σ R`.
```

```suggestion
- If `R` is a topological (semi)ring, then so is `PowerSeries σ R`.
- If the topology of `R` is T0 or T2, then so is that of `PowerSeries σ R`.
- If `R` is a `UniformAddGroup`, then so is `PowerSeries σ R`.
- If `R` is complete, then so is `PowerSeries σ R`.
```

This can also be written as
```suggestion
    Filter.Tendsto (X · : σ → MvPowerSeries σ R) Filter.cofinite (nhds 0) := by
```

```suggestion
  rw [tendsto_pi_nhds]
  simp_rw [apply_eq_coeff]
  intro d s hs
  replace hs : 0 ∈ s := by simpa only [map_zero] using mem_of_mem_nhds hs
  simp_rw [Filter.mem_map, Filter.mem_cofinite, ← Set.preimage_compl, coeff_X]
  by_cases h : ∃ i, d = Finsupp.single i 1
  · obtain ⟨i, rfl⟩ := h
    apply (Set.finite_singleton i).subset
    intro x
    by_cases hx : x = i <;>
      simp [Finsupp.single_eq_single_iff, Ne.symm, hx, hs]
  · convert Set.finite_empty
    rw [Set.eq_empty_iff_forall_not_mem]
    intro x
    rwa [Set.mem_preimage, Set.not_mem_compl_iff, if_neg]
    tauto
```

```suggestion
  exact fun d ↦ tendsto_atTop_of_eventually_const fun n hn ↦
```

```suggestion
    suffices ∀ x : R, {x} ∈ nhds x by exact this 0
```

```suggestion
    ∏ i ∈ s, (1 + f i) = ∑ t ∈ s.powerset, t.prod f := by
```
Should this go elsewhere?
Let me move it to Basic.

```suggestion
/-- `MvPowerSeries.coeff` is continuous. -/
```
This can probably be shortened using dot-notation
Indeed, thanks for the suggestion.
Could you try using `fun_prop` here?
Sorry, I don't understand what this would mean.

```suggestion
@[fun_prop]
theorem continuous_coeff [Semiring R] (d : σ →₀ ℕ) : Continuous (MvPowerSeries.coeff R d) :=
```

```suggestion
@[fun_prop]
theorem continuous_C [Ring R] [TopologicalRing R] :
```
accidental paste?

```suggestion
theorem prod_one_add {f : ι → α} (s : Finset ι) :
    ∏ i ∈ s, (1 + f i) = ∑ t ∈ s.powerset, ∏ i ∈ t, f i := by
  simp only [add_comm (1 : α), prod_add, prod_const_one, mul_one]
```
Probably it makes sense to offer `prod_add_one` as well (and then the proof can be shortened further).

the namespace is already open, as written it will end up doubled (shouldn't the linter catch this?) (edit: it does)
```suggestion
theorem apply_eq_coeff (f : MvPowerSeries σ R) (d : σ →₀ ℕ) : f d = coeff R d f := 
  rfl
```
Better to write explicitly "multivariate"
Please add a header `## Main results` or similar.
`coefficient maps`

You can shorten this (and weaken the assumptions) using some of the API you've just built above:
```suggestion
@[fun_prop]
theorem continuous_C [Semiring R] :
    Continuous (C σ R) := by
  classical
  simp only [continuous_iff_continuousAt]
  refine fun r ↦ (tendsto_iff_coeff_tendsto _ _ _).mpr fun d ↦ ?_
  simp only [coeff_C]
  split_ifs
  · exact Filter.tendsto_id
  · exact tendsto_const_nhds
```

Here is a shortened version:
```
theorem variables_tendsto_zero [Semiring R] :
    Filter.Tendsto (X · : σ → MvPowerSeries σ R) Filter.cofinite (nhds 0) := by
  classical
  simp only [tendsto_iff_coeff_tendsto, MvPowerSeries.apply_eq_coeff, coeff_X, coeff_zero]
  refine fun d ↦ tendsto_nhds_of_eventually_eq ?_
  by_cases h : ∃ i, d = Finsupp.single i 1
  · obtain ⟨i, hi⟩ := h
    filter_upwards [Filter.eventually_cofinite_ne i] with j hj
    simp only [hi, Finsupp.single_eq_single_iff, and_false, or_false, and_true, hj.symm, if_false]
  · simpa only [ite_eq_right_iff] using 
      Filter.eventually_of_forall fun x h' ↦ (not_exists.mp h x h').elim
```
Maybe open `Filter` as well, you have a lot of `Filter.xxx` in the file
Can you show the stronger statement that if `(constantCoeff σ R f) ^ n` tends to 0, i.e. it is _topologically_ nilpotent, then the same is true of `f`?

I am not sure it holds in general (unless, for example, `R` has some nonarchimedean topology) but I didn't find immediately a counterexample.
When `R` has teh discrete topology, this is done below, in `tendsto_pow_of_constantCoeff_nilpotent_iff`
Please use focussing dots (or restructure the proof to avoid having multiple goals)
I'm surprised by this, I thought the topologies were the same in the one-variable case (assuming discrete topology on the coefficients). What's the counterexample?
The comment is an unfortunate copy-paste from the multivariate case.

pullRequest.title: feat(RingTheory.MvPowerSeries.Topology): define the product topology on mv power series

source.title: feat(RingTheory.MvPowerSeries.Topology): a power series is the sum of its homogeneous components
feat(RingTheory.MvPowerSeries.LinearTopology): a linear topology on the ring of power series
